title: 2022-02-01 - Inside Trickbot, Russia‚Äôs Notorious Ransomware Gang
plain_text:
# Inside Trickbot, Russia‚Äôs Notorious Ransomware Gang

**[wired.com/story/trickbot-malware-group-internal-messages/](https://www.wired.com/story/trickbot-malware-group-internal-messages/)**

Matt Burgess February 1, 2022

When the phones and computer networks went down at Ridgeview Medical Center‚Äôs three
[hospitals on October 24, 2020, the medical group resorted to a Facebook post to warn its](https://www.facebook.com/ridgeviewhospitalsandclinics/posts/3602349299816921)
[patients about the disruption. One local volunteer-run fire department said ambulances were](https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=3672210586176490&id=286134231450826)
being diverted to other hospitals; officials [reported patients and staff were safe. The](https://www.swnewsmedia.com/chanhassen_villager/news/local/unusual-network-activity-at-ridgeview-medical-center/article_5fc12f6e-c320-59d4-9ad4-24f5cb985a36.html)
[downtime at the Minnesota medical facilities was no technical glitch; reports quickly linked](https://krebsonsecurity.com/2020/10/fbi-dhs-hhs-warn-of-imminent-credible-ransomware-threat-against-u-s-hospitals/comment-page-1/)
the activity to one of Russia‚Äôs most notorious ransomware gangs.

Thousands of miles away, just two days later members of the Trickbot cybercrime group
privately gloated over what easy targets hospitals and health care providers make. ‚ÄúYou see,
how fast, hospitals and centers reply,‚Äù Target, a key member of the Russia-linked malware
gang, boasted in messages to one of their colleagues. The exchange is included in
previously unreported documents, seen by WIRED, that consist of hundreds of messages
sent between Trickbot members and detail the inner workings of the notorious hacking
group. ‚ÄúAnswers from the rest, [take] days. And from the ridge immediately the answer flew
in,‚Äù Target wrote.


-----

As Target typed, members of Trickbot were in the middle of launching a huge wave of
ransomware attacks against hospitals across the United States. Their aim: to force hospitals
busy responding to the surging Covid-19 pandemic to quickly pay ransoms. The series of
[attacks prompted urgent warnings from federal agencies, including the Cybersecurity and](https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/ncas/alerts/aa20-302a)
Infrastructure Security Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. ‚ÄúFuck clinics in the
usa this week,‚Äù Target said as they gave the instruction to start targeting a list of 428
hospitals. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs gonna be a panic.‚Äù

The documents seen by WIRED include messages between senior members of Trickbot,
dated from the summer and autumn of 2020, and expose how the group planned to expand
its hacking operations. They lay bare key members‚Äô aliases and show the ruthless attitude of
members of the criminal gang.

The messages were sent in the months before and shortly after US Cyber Command
disrupted much of Trickbot‚Äôs infrastructure and temporarily stopped the group‚Äôs work. Since
[then the group has scaled up its operations and evolved its malware, and it continues to](https://www.zdnet.com/article/trickbot-will-now-try-to-crash-researcher-pcs-to-stop-reverse-engineering-attempts/)
target businesses around the world. While Russia‚Äôs  Federal Security Service has recently
[arrested members of the REvil ransomware gang‚Äîfollowing diplomatic efforts between](https://www.wired.com/story/russia-revil-ransomware-arrests-ukraine/)
presidents Joe Biden and Vladimir Putin‚ÄîTrickbot‚Äôs inner circle has so far been left relatively
unscathed.

‚ÄúThey're trying to infect as many people as possible.‚Äù

Limor Kessem, IBM Security

The Trickbot group evolved from the banking trojan Dyre around the end of 2015, when
Dyre‚Äôs members [were arrested. The gang has grown its original banking trojan to become an](https://www.forbes.com/sites/thomasbrewster/2016/02/08/russia-arrests-dyre-malware-masterminds/?sh=63e2f942227f)
all-purpose hacking toolkit; individual modules, which operate like plugins, allow its operators
to deploy Ryuk and Conti ransomware, while other functions enable keylogging and data
collection. ‚ÄúI don't know any other malware families that have so many modules or extended
functionalities,‚Äù says Vlad Pasca, a senior malware analyst at security company Lifars who
has decompiled Trickbot‚Äôs code. That sophistication has helped the gang, also known as
Wizard Spider, collect millions of dollars from victims.

A core team of around half a dozen criminals sits at the heart of Trickbot‚Äôs operations,
according to the documents reviewed by WIRED and security experts who track the group.
Each member has their own specialities, such as managing teams of coders or heading up
ransomware deployments. At the head of the organization is Stern. (Like all the monikers
used in this story, the real-world name, or names, behind the handles are unknown. They
are, however, the identities the group uses when talking to each other.)

‚ÄúHe is the boss of Trickbot,‚Äù says Alex Holden, who is CEO of cybersecurity firm Hold
Security and has knowledge of the workings of the gang. Stern acts like a CEO of the
Trickbot group and communicates with other members who are at a similar level. They may


-----

also report to others who are unknown, Holden says. Stern does not get into the technical
side as much,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúHe wants reports. He wants more communication. He wants to
make high-level decisions.‚Äù

On August 20, 2020, the chat logs‚Äîprovided by a cybersecurity source with knowledge of
the group‚Äîshow Target briefing Stern on how the group would expand in the coming weeks.
‚ÄúThere will be 6 offices for sure and 50-80 people by the end of September,‚Äù Target said in
one of a flurry of 19 messages. These offices are believed to be based in Russia‚Äôs secondlargest city, Saint Petersburg. Kimberly Goody, director of cybercrime analysis at security firm
Mandiant, says the group ‚Äúmost likely‚Äù has a significant presence there. Current estimates
say Trickbot has anywhere from 100 to 400 members, making it one of the largest
cybercrime groups in existence.

Messages between Target and Stern show that in mid-2020 the group was spending money
on three main areas. Two offices‚Äî‚Äúone main and one new for training‚Äù‚Äîwere being used for
the current operators‚Äô expenses and expansion. ‚ÄúHacker offices,‚Äù where 20-plus people
worked, would be used for interviews, equipment, servers, and hiring, Target said. And
finally, there would be an office for ‚Äúprogrammers‚Äù and their equipment. ‚ÄúA good team leader
has already been hired, and he will help gather the team,‚Äù Target continued. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure that
everything will pay off, so I‚Äôm not nervous.‚Äù

Throughout the conversations viewed by WIRED, the group makes various references to
‚Äúsenior managers‚Äù working as part of Trickbot and its businesslike structure. ‚ÄúThere is
generally a core team of developers,‚Äù Goody explains. ‚ÄúThere's a manager who oversees
development work, and they have coders that work under them on specific projects.‚Äù
Members of the group are encouraged to propose ideas, such as new scripts or malware,
that developers could work on, Goody says, and generally the lower-level workers don‚Äôt talk
to their senior colleagues. Most of the group‚Äôs internal conversations, according to various
sources‚Äîincluding US court documents‚Äîhappen through instant messages on Jabber
servers.

A gang member going by the moniker Professor oversees much of the ransomware
deployment work, Goody says. ‚ÄúProfessor, who we believe also goes by the name Alter,
seems to be a relatively significant player in terms of managing these specific ransomware
deployment operations,‚Äù Goody says, ‚Äúas well as requesting development of specific tools
that would help enable those.‚Äù She adds that Professor has been linked to Conti ransomware
operations in the last year and ‚Äúappears to lead multiple sub-teams or has multiple team
leaders‚Äù that report to them.

That wouldn‚Äôt be the only working relationship Trickbot‚Äôs team has with outside parties. In the
conversations seen by WIRED, Target says the group will ‚Äúlearn to collaborate‚Äù with those
behind the Ryuk ransomware, indicating that the two organizations are largely separate. And
while the Trickbot group hasn‚Äôt been linked to hacking operations run by the Russian state‚Äî
[such as the activities of Sandworm‚Äîthe core members of the gang make reference to](https://www.wired.com/story/sandworm-kremlin-most-dangerous-hackers/)


-----

Kremlin-backed activities. Stern mentioned setting up an office for government topics in
[July 2020. In response, Professor said the hacking group Cozy Bear is ‚Äúworking their way](https://www.wired.com/story/cozy-bear-dukes-russian-hackers-new-tricks/)
down the list‚Äù of potential Covid-19 targets.

In one set of internal conversations, Target answers questions from a group member who is
concerned about being caught. The person is worried that colleagues could expose their
locations, through leaking their IP addresses, when they don‚Äôt use a VPN to mask their
whereabouts. Target says IP address exposure shouldn‚Äôt be a problem: ‚ÄúHere it is
guaranteed that no one will touch you and you are probably not going to fly somewhere
anyway.‚Äù

Prior to the REvil arrests, the Kremlin and Russian authorities spent years allowing
ransomware groups believed to be based in the country to operate with relative impunity.
‚ÄúThere seems to be very deliberate separation and non-attacks of any Russian interests by
Trickbot, Ryuk, Emotet, and Conti because they don‚Äôt want confrontation with the
government,‚Äù Holden says. However, not all of Trickbot‚Äôs members are in Russia. The
conversations among the group viewed by WIRED reveal at least two members appear to be
[based in Belarus‚Äîduring the summer of 2020 when Belarus shut down the internet Stern](https://www.wired.co.uk/article/belarus-protests-telegram)
said that one member, a coder called Hof, would not be online until ‚Äúthe internet problem in
Belarus is solved.‚Äù

These exchanges likely comprise only a small element of the group‚Äôs interactions. Some
details of TrickBot‚Äôs inner workings were also revealed in June and October 2021, when the
US Department of Justice unsealed and unredacted charges against two alleged Trickbot
members, Alla Witte and Vladimir Dunaev. The indictment, which also covers other unnamed
members of the Trickbot group, focuses on the group‚Äôs hacking and money laundering but
also provides snippets of conversations. Goody says some private communication channels
can contain dozens of members of the group.

Coders and developers recruited by Trickbot are drawn in from job postings on dark web
forums but also on open web Russian-language freelancer websites, the DOJ indictment
says. While many of the job ads are hiding in plain sight, they don‚Äôt explicitly say successful
applicants will be working for one of the world‚Äôs most ruthless cybercriminal groups. One job
ad the indictment points to calls for someone who is an experienced reverse engineer and
knows the coding language C++. The ad, which has long-since expired, says the job was
focused around web browsers on Windows, involved working remotely, and had a budget of
$7,000. A long-term position would potentially be possible if the work was completed
successfully, the ad says.

Holden says Trickbot uses multiple layers during its hiring process in an effort to weed out
those without the technical skills needed, and also cybersecurity companies trying to gather
intelligence. Anyone applying for work has to pass an initial screening before moving on to


-----

tough skills tests, he says. The questions are very complex technologically, he explains.
Goody adds that penetration testers working for the group can be paid $1,500 per month,
plus a cut of ransoms that are paid.

During the recruitment process, Holden says, it is ‚Äúacknowledged‚Äù that these aren‚Äôt everyday
roles. Holden says he has seen ads that tell potential recruits they will be working for a
startup involved in bug bounties, and that most of its funding comes from abroad. ‚ÄúThe
majority understand that this is blackhat and asking for the commercial target,‚Äù Trickbot
conversations within the DOJ indictment say, referring to criminal hacking activities. ‚ÄúWe
need to stop communicating with idiots.‚Äù

The two alleged members of Trickbot named by the DOJ‚ÄîWitte and Dunaev‚Äîwere arrested
by law enforcement outside of Russia. Witte, a 55-year-old Latvian national who lived in
Suriname, was arrested in June 2021 while traveling to Miami and is charged with 19 counts
that range from identity theft to bank fraud. She‚Äôs [accused of being one of Trickbot‚Äôs malware](https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/latvian-national-charged-alleged-role-transnational-cybercrime-organization)
developers and allegedly exposed herself after hosting Trickbot‚Äôs malware on her personal
domain name. Dunaev, 38, was extradited from the Republic of Korea to Ohio in October
[2021 and is also accused of developing Trickbot‚Äôs malware.](https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/russian-national-extradited-united-states-face-charges-alleged-role-cybercriminal)

Despite the arrests and wider ransomware crackdowns in Russia, the Trickbot group has not
exactly gone into hiding. Toward the end of last year, the group [boosted its operations, says](https://securityintelligence.com/posts/trickbot-gang-doubles-down-enterprise-infection/)
Limor Kessem, an executive security advisor at IBM Security. ‚ÄúThey're trying to infect as
many people as possible by contracting out the infection,‚Äù she says. Since the start of 2022,
the IBM security team has seen Trickbot increase its efforts to evade security protections and
[conceal its activity. The FBI also formally linked the use of the Diavol ransomware to Trickbot](https://securityintelligence.com/posts/trickbot-bolsters-layered-defenses-prevent-injection/)
at the beginning of the year. ‚ÄúTrickbot doesn't seem to be targeting very specifically; I think
what they have is numerous affiliates working with them, and whoever brings the most
money is welcome to stay,‚Äù Limor says.

Holden too says he has seen evidence that Trickbot is ramping up its operations. ‚ÄúLast year
they invested more than $20 million into their infrastructure and growth of their organization,‚Äù
he explains, citing internal messages he has seen. This money, he says, is being spent on
everything Trickbot does. ‚ÄúStaffing, technology, communications, development, extortion‚Äù are
all getting extra investment, he says. The move points to a future where‚Äîafter the takedown
of REvil‚Äîthe Trickbot group may become the primary Russia-linked cybercrime gang. ‚ÄúYou
expand in the hope of getting that money back in spades,‚Äù Holden says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like they are
planning to close the shop. It‚Äôs not like they are planning to downsize or run and hide.‚Äù

More Great WIRED Stories
